job_title: Anonymous Employee in Bossier City, LA
pros: Helping the students succeed. Knowing that the students appreciated you for helping them.
cons: Not everyone was born to be a leader. They tend to promote people based on factors that look good on paper for reporting. If you are not a member of the right “click” you will be iced out.  Just because this a community college, it doesn’t  give you the right to act so petty. We are at work, grow up.   You are supposed to be setting the example to your minions.

pros: BPCC is a good place to work.  We have a very student centered environment.  We have relatively small class sizes with more personal instruction.  The majority of faculty are there because they love working with students.  Our buildings are well kept up and grants are written for items that are needed.  BPCC is well thought of in the community and tries to meet local employer needs.
cons: The salary is not great.  Raises are not given regularly.  (No raise for my position in 8 years.)  Being a part of the state system, we are usually under a hiring and spending freeze.  The salary structure is flawed in relation to compensation for equal pay for equal jobs and pay not based on experience and level of education level of the instructor.

job_title: Adjunct Instructor in Bossier City, LA
pros: Teaching at the community college level can be personally rewarding, and has advantages if you want to work part time.
cons: Office culture was very "clickish", and power came mostly from dept. heads. However, you must be very careful who you favor, and how you approach "favored" staff and faculty.

pros: Small environment, helps community get to the school.
cons: The school only hires people who are family members or friends of original staff. The lack of diversity in the faculty, the chancellors, the administration, the executives, is glaring. Pay is commensurate with all the other colleges in the LCTCS system.
